abstract.p: Methyl-CpG binding protein 2 gene (MECP2) testing is indicated for patients with numerous clinical presentations, including Rett syndrome (classic and atypical), unexplained neonatal encephalopathy, Angelman syndrome, nonspecific mental retardation, autism (females), and an X-linked family history of developmental delay. Because of this complexity, a gender-specific approach for comprehensive MECP2 gene testing is described. Briefly, sequencing of exons 1 to 4 of MECP2 is recommended for patients with a Rett syndrome phenotype, unexplained neonatal encephalopathy, an Angelman syndrome phenotype (with negative 15q11-13 analysis), nonspecific mental retardation, or autism (females). Additional testing for large-scale MECP2 deletions is recommended for patients with Rett syndrome or Angelman syndrome phenotypes (with negative 15q11-13 analysis) following negative sequencing. Alternatively, testing for large-scale MECP2 duplications is recommended for males presenting with mental retardation, an X-linked family history of developmental delay, and a significant proportion of previously described clinical features (particularly a history of recurrent respiratory infections).

sec.title: MECP2 Structure and Function In Vivo
sec.p:
The methyl-CpG binding protein 2 (MeCP2) is encoded by MECP2 (OMIM 300005), which is an approximately 76-kilobase gene that maps to Xq28. 1
–4 MECP2 is encoded by 4 exons that give rise to 2 isoforms, MECP2e2 and MECP2e1. These 2 isoforms are encoded by exons 2, 3, and 4 and by exons 1, 3, and 4, respectively. 5 This protein contains 4 significant domains, including a methyl binding domain, a transcription repression domain, a nuclear localization signal, and a carboxyl terminal domain (Table 1). 6
–12

sec.title: Clinical Presentations Associated With MECP2 Mutations
Rett Syndrome
sec.p:
Rett syndrome is a relatively common genetic cause of mental retardation, which affects approximately 1/10 000 to 15 000 females and, albeit extremely rarely, males (most commonly those males with X-chromosome aneuploidy). 28
–37 This syndrome was first described by Andreas Rett in 1966 and follows an X-linked dominant inheritance pattern. 38 The clinical hallmarks of Rett syndrome include normal development until approximately 6 to 18 months of life, followed by a subsequent slowing of neurological development and regression of fine motor and communication skills, microcephaly, seizures, autistic behaviors, ataxia, and stereotypic hand movements. 38 –40 Individuals diagnosed with Rett syndrome in the clinical setting can be categorized as having classic or atypical Rett syndrome, based on their clinical presentations. 41

sec.title: Females with Rett syndrome
sec.p:
Approximately 80% of females with Rett syndrome have a sequence mutation in MECP2. 42
–45 The recurrent types of mutations identified by polymerase chain reaction–based sequencing (missense, nonsense, and deletions) exhibit MeCP2 domain specificity and each type comprises 13% to 35% of the total number of MECP2 sequence mutations (Table 2). 42,44
–51 Approximately 90% of MECP2 mutations cluster in exon 4, whereas ∼7% are found in exon 3. 49 Regardless of location within MECP2, the most frequent type of mutation seen in patients with Rett syndrome is a single nucleotide change, which accounts for approximately 80% of the currently described MECP2 mutations.47,49,50,52,53 Specifically, cytosine to thymine (C>T) nucleotide changes comprise nearly 65% of all described MECP2 mutations, with the alteration of arginine (CGA) to a premature stop codon (TGC) being the most common. 50 –52,54,55

In addition to sequence mutations, recent studies have identified gross rearrangements of the MECP2 gene in both classic and atypical female patients with Rett syndrome. Nearly 80% of the reported cases with large-scale deletions in MECP2 meet clinical standards for classic Rett syndrome; the remaining 20% of patients are clinically characterized as presenting with atypical Rett syndrome. In addition, of the patients with Rett syndrome studied who are mutation-negative by traditional polymerase chain reaction–based sequencing, approximately 32% of classic and 6.5% of atypical patients have a deletion of the MECP2 gene. 45,48,56
–65 Although these deletions vary in size and location within the gene, they most commonly include exons 3 to 4 of MECP2. Although not all studies included informative data, the large-scale deletions identified in 17 reported cases extend into interleukin-1 receptor-associated kinase (IRAK1; OMIM 300283) located approximately 0.04 megabases centromeric to MECP2. 60,62
–65 The phenotypes of these individuals were not noted to be more or less severe than those without the IRAK1 deletions. Interestingly, female patients who are monosomy for the distal portion of Xq typically have a normal physical phenotype but often have premature ovarian failure. 66
–71 These deletions typically span the Xq26-Xqter regions, and the gene responsible for premature ovarian failure has now been localized between the Xq27.2/Xq27.3 and Xqter regions. 72 Presumably, because the entire MECP2 gene and its regulatory elements are absent, these mega-deletions do not result in the Rett syndrome phenotype associated with more localized, smaller-scale MECP2 deletions that lead to an altered MeCP2 protein product.

sec.title: Males with Rett syndrome
sec.p:
As previously mentioned, studies have shown that sequence mutations of MECP2 are a cause of classic Rett syndrome in males. Alternatively, severe neonatal-onset encephalopathy has been identified in male patients with MECP2 mutations. Sequence mutations in the methyl binding domain of MECP2 are most commonly found in males presenting with a Rett syndrome or Rett syndrome–like phenotype who also have X-chromosome aneuploidy. 34,73 –75 Conversely, mutations in the transcription repression domain of MECP2 are most commonly found in males presenting with severe neonatal-onset encephalopathy, microcephaly, dystonia, involuntary movements, severe seizures, and prominent breathing abnormalities without documented mosaicism. 33,76-78 These MECP2 sequence mutations have been characterized as causative because they have also been identified in female patients with Rett syndrome. 30
–37,74
–83 However, a number of reported MECP2 sequence mutations identified in male patients with nonspecific mental retardation have not been identified in a clinically affected female population.29,36,75,80,81,83-85 In addition, mutations identified in seemingly affected males have been reported in apparently unaffected females with random X-chromosome inactivation. 29,84-86 Therefore, the pathogenicity of these mutations has not been established. As the number of male patients sequenced for MECP2 increases and knowledge about these mutations expands, these unclassified variants will be more accurately delineated as causative mutations or benign polymorphic variants.

In addition to sequence mutations, Hardwick et al 65 detected a male patient with neonatal encephalopathy and a deletion of exons 3 and 4 of MECP2. This patient also had an affected sister with classic Rett syndrome and a typical X-inactivation pattern (52:48) and an affected mother with mild learning disabilities and a skewed X-inactivation (93:7). Therefore, large-scale deletions can be a cause of neonatal encephalopathy in males and should be considered in light of this familial case report.

sec.title: Angelman Syndrome
sec.p: MECP2 mutations have also been reported in patients with a phenotype similar to that of Angelman syndrome. In fact, some speak of a Rett-Angelman syndrome spectrum. 87 Like Rett syndrome, Angelman syndrome is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by severe mental retardation, absent speech, ataxia, seizures, and dysmorphic features. A genetic abnormality of chromosome 15q11-13 accounts for nearly 85% of Angelman syndrome patients, whereas the remaining ∼15% do not have an identifiable etiology. 88,89 In 2 studies, patients with a clinical diagnosis of Angelman syndrome and no abnormality of 15q11-13 were screened for sequence mutations in the MECP2 gene. 75,88 From the 110 Angelman syndrome patients included in these 2 studies, MECP2 mutations were identified in 7 patients (2 males and 5 females). 75,88 A period of regression was subsequently identified in a subset of these patients, and these individuals were therefore classified as having Rett syndrome. However, a number of patients were still considered clinically to have an Angelman syndrome–like phenotype with an MECP2 mutation.

sec.title: Nonspecific Mental Retardation
sec.p: MECP2 sequence mutations have been identified in both male and female patients with nonsyndromic cognitive defects. 55,75,84-86,90-93 The estimated frequency of MECP2 mutations in this cohort ranges from 0.2% to 2%. 85,90 Interestingly, a study aimed at analyzing the number of exon 1 sequencing mutations in a cohort of 554 female and 200 male patients with nonspecific developmental delay/mental retardation identified 4 female but no male patients with an exon 1 mutation.93 Although these results do not eliminate the possibility that males with nonspecific mental retardation may have mutations in exon 1, they do highlight the importance of exon 1 sequence analysis in female patients with nonspecific mental retardation, including those patients whose diagnostic MECP2 sequence analysis was performed prior to the discovery of the current exon 1 of MECP2 in 2000. 5

sec.title: Autism
sec.p:
In addition to Rett syndrome, Angelman syndrome, and nonspecific mental retardation, autism is another genetic neurodevelopmental disorder that has been associated with sequence-based mutations of MECP2. Autism is a complex genetic neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by extreme social and communicative difficulties and patterns of behavior that are restricted and/or stereotypic. 26,94 Several studies have identified female patients with autism and MECP2 mutations; these mutations include both a small number of novel deleterious mutations and a majority of Rett syndrome–associated mutations. 95
–99 The reported incidence of MECP2 mutations in patients with autism is 3% to 13%. 96,100

As with previously discussed differential diagnoses, the majority of the sequence mutations identified in patients with autism (primarily female) are found in the coding region of MECP2. To date, only one likely pathogenic sequence mutation in MECP2 (guanine to cytosine substitution at base 617; c.617G>C) has been reported in a male with autism. 99 However, a few studies have also analyzed the 3′-untranslated region in patients with autism and have found that, despite the high innate sequence variability, this region also contains significant sequence alterations identified primarily in the population of males with autism. 98,99 Specifically, a total of 14 variants were identified in this region, of which at least 7 were in conserved nucleotides. 98,99 Further studies performed on 4 of the male patients with autism and changes in conserved nucleotides of the 3′-untranslated region identified significantly lower MECP2 mRNA levels as compared to normal male controls selected based on their absence of MECP2 sequence mutations. 99 As mentioned above, only 1 male patient with autism has been identified with a sequence-based mutation of MECP2 in the coding region; however, based on these studies of the 3′-untranslated region, it is plausible that analysis of this region will be more significant for this cohort of patients in the future. It is necessary to perform analysis of the 3′-untranslated region on a number of male and female patients with a variety of other indications associated with MECP2 sequence mutations (ie, Rett syndrome, Angelman syndrome, nonspecific mental retardation) before this specific population (males with autism) is considered exclusively for these mutations. In addition, studying an increased number of unaffected controls will be useful in determining the significance of mutations found in this highly variable region. Therefore, although current literature does not support clinical testing of male patients with autism for MECP2 mutations, this cohort of patients should be closely monitored, as continued research may elucidate the necessity for testing in the future.

sec.title: Cerebral Palsy
sec.p:
Last, cerebral palsy is a clinical diagnosis used to describe patients with impaired control of their movements due to a defect in the developing brain, which does not worsen over time. 101 For the purposes of this article, cerebral palsy will be defined as a static encephalopathy with spasticity that is not otherwise explained. These individuals may also present with a number of additional conditions, including, but not limited to, mental retardation, ataxia, abnormal gait, and seizures. One important physical clue can be the presence of “silver-gray” hair in males with cerebral palsy and MECP2 mutations. Although historically associated with brain injury, a variety of scientific studies have strongly suggested a genetic basis for a portion of the population with cerebral palsy. 102
–107 Based on the emerging strong evidence for genetic etiologies of cerebral palsy and the prevalence of MECP2 mutations in a variety of clinically abnormal phenotypes, polymerase chain reaction–based sequencing of the MECP2 gene is recommended for part of the etiologic evaluation in patients diagnosed with cerebral palsy. 108

sec.title: MECP2 Duplication
sec.p: The mutations historically associated with MECP2 are loss-of-function mutations. Therefore, in an effort to investigate the therapeutic feasibility of enhancing endogenous MeCP2 or introducing a wild-type MeCP2 using gene therapy in patients with Rett syndrome, a mouse model was developed that transgenically expressed MeCP2 under the endogenous human promoter. 109 Interestingly, the results of this study demonstrated that even modest levels of excess MeCP2 can cause a progressive neurological phenotype. 109

Large-scale duplications of MECP2 have been identified in a population of male patients with distinguishable clinical findings, including a history of recurrent respiratory infections, intellectual disability, limited/lack of speech, limited/lack of ambulation, hypotonia, swallowing dysfunction, and seizures. 110
–115 Approximately ∼80% of reported cases describe a history of recurrent respiratory infections, and this finding may prove to be one of the key factors in distinguishing this group of patients from the large number of other known autosomal and X-linked syndromes. Before testing such as multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification was available, disomy of the distal Xq region was observed in a number of patients closely matching the clinical features described in these mutations now attributed specifically to duplication of MECP2 at Xq28, including microcephaly, developmental delay/mental retardation, hypotonia, hypertelorism, and recurrent respiratory infections. 66,116
–122

Duplications in the Xq28 region range in size from 0.2 to 2.3 megabases. 110,112,113 The most common duplicated region includes both the MECP2 and L1CAM (L1 cell adhesion molecule; OMIM 308840) genes. However, the critical gene in this group of male patients seems to be the MECP2 gene, as there are reported patients with the appropriate clinical presentation and duplication of MECP2 without duplication of L1CAM. 111,113 Studies to date do not clearly indicate whether the size of the duplication or the inclusion of the L1CAM gene region influences the severity of the phenotype. One report of a triplication of MECP2 resulted in a more severe phenotype than in patients with MECP2 duplications. 110

In addition to the affected males with MECP2 duplications, mothers and other female family members of these male patients have been shown to be carriers of the MECP2 duplication. 110,112,113 These female carriers are typically phenotypically normal and consistently have favorably skewed X-inactivation, likely minimizing the expression of the duplicated MECP2 gene region. Therefore, although this MECP2 duplication has little impact on the phenotype of female carriers, it will be an important factor in their reproductive genetic counseling.

sec.title: Summary of Reported MECP2 Mutations
sec.p: A summary of reported MECP2 mutations characterized by gender and phenotype is included in Table 3. Specifically, MECP2 sequence analysis is the highest yield genetic test to perform on patients with a suspected clinical diagnosis of Rett syndrome, as this analysis identifies a genetic etiology in ∼80% of suspected Rett syndrome cases. In addition, this testing has identified MECP2 mutations in patients with differential diagnoses that include Angelman syndrome (without 15q11-13 abnormalities), autism (females), unexplained neonatal encephalopathy, and nonspecific mental retardation. Current literature also supports large-scale deletion testing of MECP2 in the absence of an MECP2 sequence mutation in patients with classic or atypical Rett syndrome phenotype, as the yield is ∼32% and ∼6.5%, respectively. No large-scale studies have been performed to assess the yield of large-scale deletion testing in MECP2 sequence-negative patients with alternative testing indications (autism, nonspecific mental retardation, and cerebral palsy). Therefore, it will be critical to monitor the current literature and to include the large-scale deletion testing for these alternative clinical phenotypes if it is indicated in the future.

sec.p: Although general disomy of the distal Xq has been reported in males over the past few decades, the gene responsible for the phenotype associated with these duplications has recently been identified as MECP2. A preliminary compilation of relevant clinical features has begun to emerge, including an X-linked family history of developmental delay and, notably, a history of recurrent respiratory infections. As this cohort of patients continues to grow, it will be critical to monitor the size of the duplication (including inclusion or exclusion of L1CAM) and the clinical presentation of the affected patients to further refine the genotype:phenotype correlation emerging in these individuals.

sec.title: Suggested Testing Algorithm for MECP2
sec.p: Based on current literature, testing of MECP2 is indicated for a variety of clinical presentations, including Rett syndrome (classic and atypical), unexplained neonatal encephalopathy, Angelman syndrome, nonspecific mental retardation, autism (females), and an X-linked family history of developmental delay. Because of this complexity, a suggested approach for comprehensive MECP2 gene testing is described for females and males in Figure 1A and 1B, respectively.

caption.p: Recommended algorithm for MECP2 testing in females (A) and in males (B). *One reported large-scale deletion with this clinical presentation to date.59 **Consider testing if negative for 15q11-13 abnormality (including chromosome 15 methylation and UBE3A sequencing). RTT, Rett syndrome; PCR, polymerase chain reaction; MECP2, methyl CpG-binding protein 2; MLPA, multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification; MR, mental retardation; FISH, fluorescence in situ hybridization; UBE3A, ubiquitin-protein ligase E3A.

sec.p: Briefly, as illustrated in the recommended algorithm, polymerase chain reaction–based sequencing of exons 1 to 4 of MECP2 should be offered to patients with a Rett syndrome (classic or atypical) phenotype, unexplained neonatal encephalopathy, an Angelman syndrome phenotype (with negative 15q11-13 analysis), nonspecific mental retardation, or autism (females). Additional testing for large-scale deletions of MECP2 should be performed on patients with a Rett syndrome (classic or atypical) or an Angelman syndrome (with negative 15q11-13 analysis) phenotype when no sequence mutation is identified in MECP2. Patients with an Angelman syndrome–like phenotype are included in this large-scale deletion testing of MECP2 because the clinical presentation of this cohort overlaps extensively with that of patients with Rett syndrome. Alternatively, when patients (male) present with developmental delay/mental retardation, an X-linked family history of developmental delay/mental retardation, and a significant proportion of the clinical features described (most notably a history of recurrent respiratory infections), testing for large-scale duplication (ie, fluorescence in situ hybridization, multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification) of MECP2 is indicated.

sec.title: Current Limitations
sec.p: It is critical to note that this algorithm is limited by the testing currently available and therefore does not include testing for a variety of epigenetic factors, such as imprinting and methylation, or mRNA expression levels, which also may play a significant role in the normal function of MeCP2. As additional information about the structure, function, and interaction of MECP2 with other genes becomes available, and as the availability of clinical testing continues to broaden, this algorithm can be modified to incorporate any new, relevant diagnostic testing. In addition, it is important to be mindful of new studies that may provide evidence for inclusion of other clinical phenotypes into the testing algorithm (ie, males with autism) or for expansion of the testing recommended for a particular clinical presentations (ie, large-scale deletion studies for females with autism).
